awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Machine Learning Enhanced Automated Circuit Configuration and Evaluation of Power Converters
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of power electronics to automate complex circuit design. While significant progress has been made in advancing modeling simulation and verifying electrical power converters, the process of designing such devices remains inefficient in terms of time and cost. The state-of-the-art circuit design of power converters relies heavily on human experts to select the optimal topology and search for design parameters with human experience and intuitions.  This process can be very time-consuming, inefficient, and labor-intensive. The proposed software may help power electronics engineers consider a wide range of novel concepts more rapidly and cost-effectively before selecting an engineering-optimal architecture for high-fidelity design and evaluation.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of technology that integrates recent breakthroughs in machine learning, power electronics, data analytics, simulation software, and optimization to automate the circuit design of electrical power converters.  The technology may also facilitate the integration of the proposed software tools into existing power-converter design workflows. The technology seeks to automatically generate and evaluate power converter designs with physics-based Reduced Order Models: automatically evolving architecture concepts toward the optimal system configurations and automatically generating, evaluating and optimizing architectures within acceptable performance uncertainties while satisfying the desired outputs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Dearborn
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Dearborn

por.por_cntn:
This I-Corps project is based on the development of technology that integrates recent breakthroughs in machine learning, power electronics, data analytics, simulation software, and optimization to automate the circuit design of electrical power converters. The ML-ACCEPT software is taking a significant step to help power electronics engineers consider a wider range of more novel concepts more rapidly and cost-effectively before selecting an engineering-optimal architecture for high-fidelity design and evaluation.

The team has conducted more than 180 individual interviews. They arranged local and national travel to relevant expos, symposiums, and meetings, making their best efforts to connect with researchers, industry professionals, and other potential market participants to identify desired improvements and changes to currently available solutions.

Additionally, the team took full advantage of these golden opportunities to have face-to-face discussions with a number of potential customers, partners, and competitors in the marketplace. Based on this, the team was able to secure knowledge and feedback from potential market partners and better understand the developed technology’s capabilities as they pursue market entry.

The ML-ACCEPT software targets the multi-billion-dollar annual electronic design automation (EDA) market. A Non-Disclosure Agreement (NDA) has been signed with an industry partner to pursue further collaboration. The team plans to pursue the NSF STTR Phase I proposal. Meanwhile, they were able to secure additional funding from the Michigan Economic Development Corporation and University of Michigan Innovation Partnerships to continue the R&D phase.

The broader impact of this I-Corps project is the development of power electronics to automate complex circuit design. The team disseminates the developed technology through publications, presentations, and outreach programs to raise public awareness of machine learning applications in emerging energy domains. Power electronics and many other industries will benefit from using this transformative technology to automate complex circuit designs. The large audience and dissemination efforts will ensure ample exposure for all products.

 


Last Modified: 05/01/2024
Modified by: Wencong Su
